awd_titl_txt: The Many Facets of Coenzyme B12 Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Thomas Brunold from the University of Wisconsin-Madison to study the chemistry of vitamin B12.  Vitamins are necessary nutrients because they assist in various chemical changes that take place in living systems.  Vitamin B12 is extraordinary because it is one of the few molecules in biology where the metal cobalt is found.  In addition, the cobalt atom is bonded to carbon in vitamin B12, a connection that is very rarely seen in biology.  The research applies state-of-the-art scientific methods to understand how this unusual bond is made, and how it is used in three specific biological systems.  Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project gain a thorough understanding of how the special chemistry of cobalt contributes to biological processes.  The broader impacts of this work are enhanced by an open-house laboratory workshop and an undergraduate inorganic laboratory with examples derived from the research resulting from this award.

Enzymes that bind corrinoid cofactors catalyze a number of unique chemical transformations, including cobalt (Co)- carbon (C) bond formation (e.g. ATP:Co(I)rrinoid adenosyltransferases [ACATs]), radical-based rearrangement of substrates (e.g. AdoCbl-dependent enzymes), and dehalogenation of organic substrates (e.g. reductive dehalogenases [RDases]).  Reactive cob(I)alamin species are postulated as intermediates in the sterol O-acyltransferase (also called Acyl-CoA cholesterol acyltransferase or ACAT) enzyme mechanisms. A characterization of these species during enzyme turnover has not previously been attempted. The research may lead to a detailed understanding of how ACATs accomplish the formation of Co(I)Cbl intermediates and control their nucleophilicity. In the case of AdoCbl-dependent enzymes, it is widely accepted that the homolytic cleavage of the Co-C bond of AdoCbl to generate a 5'-deoxyadenosyl-based radical represents the first step in their catalytic cycles. Yet, little is known about the origin of the rate enhancement for this step displayed by Class II eliminases, which bind AdoCbl in a unique conformation. The research elucidates the mechanism used by Class II eliminases to promote homolysis of the Co-C bond of their AdoCbl cofactors in response to substrate binding. Lastly, the B12-dependent RDases have recently attracted considerable interest because they are critical for the bioremediation of organohalides. Professor Brunold and his group use a range of spectroscopic and computational methods to test the hypothesis that novel halogenated corrinoid intermediates are formed in the catalytic cycles of these enzymes.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Coenzyme B12 (adenosylcobalamin, AdoCbl) contains a reactive Co-C bond, which provides a rare example of a metal-carbon (or organometallic) bond found in a biomolecule. We used a combination of spectroscopic and computational tools to address three key questions in the field of B12 research: (i) what is the mechanism of Co-C bond formation employed by enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of AdoCbl; (ii) how can the AdoCbl-dependent enzyme ethanolamine ammonia lyase (EAL) accelerate the rate of Co-C bond homolysis by more than 10 orders of magnitude in response to substrate binding; and (iii) how do the B12-dependent reductive dehalogenases accomplish the challenging Co(II)-to-Co(I) reduction and subsequent substrate reduction. Our results provided compelling evidence that (i) all known enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of the Co-C bond of AdoCbl generate an unusual four-coordinate Co(II) species that can readily be reduced to a Co(I) intermediate, which subsequently attacks the 5?-carbon of adenosine triphosphate (ATP); (ii) the main contributor to the rate acceleration of Co-C bond homolysis accomplished by EAL is the formation of additional favorable interactions that develop between the adenosine moiety and amino acid residues in the active site as the Co-C bond lengthens; and (iii) the B12-dependent reductive dehalogenases utilize a mechanism involving outer-sphere electron transfer from a transient Co(I) intermediate as opposed to Co-C(substrate) bond formation, the latter of which had previously been proposed (an extremely important finding with regards to the development of new bioremediation catalysts).

In terms of broader impact, our results demonstrate that (i) magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) spectroscopy provides an almost ideal tool for probing the ligand-field transitions, and thus the electronic structure, of Co(II) centers in any coordination environment and (ii) the combination of molecular dynamics simulations and quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) geometry optimizations provides an extremely promising approach for the computational investigation of the molecular details of the reactions catalyzed by B12-dependent enzymes.

The collaborative and interdisciplinary nature of this project offered all graduate students involved in this research an extremely broad, well-rounded scientific education. Through the participation of undergraduate students in this project, my graduate students were given additional opportunities for mentoring and supervising untrained researchers. Collectively, these experiences have prepared my graduate students extremely well for an academic career or leadership positions in industry. Additionally, the undergraduate students working on this project gained valuable research experience that better prepared them for graduate school or increased their chances of being offered a job.


Last Modified: 06/17/2022
Modified by: Thomas C Brunold

Image
  • Graphical representation of the spectroscopic approach used in our B12 research. The combination of circularly polarized light and a static magnetic field (MCD spectroscopy) allows for the detection of Co-centered d-d transitions that are too weak to contribute to the UV-vis spectrum.
    Elizabeth Greenhalgh
    Public Domain
    Thomas C Brunold
    MCD study of B12-dependent enzyme
